title: Will Iran agree to cap its oil output before 1 July 2016?
preds: Iran seems to be winning the Opec war.
With no major OPEC talks ongoing, and no obvious pressure currently being exerted on Iran, there is virtually no chance of this happening by tomorrow.
Talk it out of a rat hole?
A cut in the next few days now looks extremely improbable. Iran has repeatedly refused to do this during the previous few months, and seems to have no particular reason to change direction now.

Iran has shown no indication that it will cut production in any of its meetings with OPEC. As its economy has been severely impacted by the previous sanctions Iran is extremely dependent on oil revenue. Not likely to cut production whilst KSA refuses to cut its production
I have no idea at all about this at all, but it's close to the deadline, so I'm hoping that the shortness of timescale will compensate for my total subject ignorance.
Oil prices plunged right after Brexit. Some recovery has been seen today.  That's about it on oil news.
Too short a time frame.  (I know, I'm late to this party.)
no need to. They benefit from herd immunity. If all the OPEC countries are collectively or individually capping, why do they need to?

Iran will want to have quotas, but they want to pump more. i think they would settle a little less that they are currently after. But i dont think it would not happen at given time frame. No new OPEC meeting at the door before  1 july so i give 0% chance to output cap by Iranians
I am forecasting based on the general news reports and GJP consensus.
Nope, and remember to bring Euros.
Iran needs the oil revenue, will likely oppose opec on principle
Not happening before July.  Opec leaders met in Vienna at the beginning of June and Iran rejected oil output cap.  Nothing has changed since.
They don't produce enough oil for a stated cap to be anything other than a symbolic genuflection to the House of Saud.

It's every country for himself when it comes to oil production.  OPEC doesn't even have power to influence it's members anymore.  Iran will keep on producing as it does not want to sacrifice output when no else is doing it.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

No way. OPEC still not working, Saudi campaign of supply destruction and discipline enforcement not done and tensions between SA and Iran remain heightened. Introduction of caps will not be done unilaterally, they will take behind the scenes negotiations, hence require more time.
Iran wants to return to its pre-sanction level of oil  before a cap is considered and that is not likely soon,
This one has bitten the dust for me!
Needs to resolve other diplomatic issues with KSA first
They have several chances to even hit the low bar of agreeing to cap and they haven't so I am bowing to the inevitable.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

Cartels operate by mutually agreeing to limit production below where supply and demand would normally intersect. This allows above market prices to be obtained by the members of the cartel.  The challenge of 'running' a cartel is that members are inclinded to cheat and over-produce, since this will lead to higher revenues for that one member-state. Eventually, more and more members will produce in excess of their production agreements, leading to a decline in prices.
FT reports OPEC members generally accept that the market is returning to equilibrium, with prices near $50, high cost production reduced and increased customer demand at the lower price.
Down 2% since I was wrong about the OPEC meeting.
OPEC met in Vienna today and did not agree on capping oil production levels.

NO change.  Self explanatory. 
Date: 2. Juni 2016 um 09:03:57 MESZ

At today’s meeting of the oil producers’ cartel in Vienna, most eyes will be on Saudi Arabia’s new energy minister, Khalid Al-Falih. But if anyone is to spring a surprise, it could be Iran. Prices have recovered to near $50 a barrel thanks to a lucky (for some) turn of events. Though Iran and Saudi Arabia failed to agree in April on a production freeze, supply disruptions since then in Iraq, Nigeria, Libya and elsewhere have in effect done their work for them; OPEC production is roughly flat at January levels despite Iran’s extra output. Logic suggests OPEC should let the rebalancing of the oil market continue at its own pace. But Iran, which is pumping at nearly full capacity, may yet confront Mr Falih by proposing a freeze. It said yesterday that it wouldn’t—but given the antagonism between the two Gulf powers, surprises can’t be ruled out

Saudi trying to cobble up a deal - I am upping my 67% likelihood to 75%, to be revised tomorrow / day after. Remember - agreement to be a part of overall cap is also a sufficient condition of the question going right.
Down 3% for scoring purposes. Still think the consensus is too low.
The price of oil continues to increase to $50 per barrel which will make everyone want to produce more.
(no change) Still above consensus. It doesn't really cost Iran anything if they were to agree to something close to current reality and the political aspects can be argued both ways.
No incentive for them to do so
No need if they see this as a legitimate concern:  http://www.wsj.com/articles/opecs-ability-to-influence-oil-supply-is-slipping-1464089971
Dropping to 2% for passage of time

Now that Iran has returned to pre-sanction production, they are now open to entertaining a discussion on a production freeze. However, if an agreement isn't reached at the OPEC meeting on June 2, I don't see Iran acting unilaterally in the following 4 weeks
The price of oil continues to increase to $50 per barrel which will make everyone want to produce more.

Deputy Oil Minister: We have no intention to freeze oil production. Deputy Oil Minister Rokneddin Javadi stated that “the volume of Iranian crude oil exports excluding condensed natural gas has increased to two million barrels per day.” Javadi added that the country “has no intention to reduce oil production.” (Mehr News Agency)

Under the present circumstances, the government and the Oil Ministry have not issued any policy or plan to the National Iranian Oil Company (NIOC) towards halting the increase in the production and exports of oil," Javadi, who also heads the state-run NIOC, told Iran's Mehr news agency, according to Reuters.

No surprise here. They're aiming for 2.2 million barrels per day by mid-summer.
http://www.reuters.com/article/idUSKCN0YD0UJ

Saudis have said they will pump as much as is required for their objective. NB: previous comments.
Iran makes clear its intention as well.

- oil prices are stable or rising based on:
  - disruptions to production in Canada and Nigeria
  - increased demand in summer months in much of the world
  - Chinese strategic stockpile increase
- Saudi Arabia is experiencing a cash shortage which would only be helped by a price increase; Iran gains a political benefit from low prices right now
  - Saudi change in Oil Minister may signal Saudi wavering on production quotas
- Iran wants to increase market share, continuing low prices will continue to force high cost producers out of the market in the short term

There is still a lot of uncertainty on oil demand due to manufacturing slow down in China, the world outside the US seeing tough economic conditions, etc. Iran does need to see higher oil revenues and a capping agreement is good for them in many ways.

Someone in Iran seems to make a conflicting statement every week now regarding the nation's willingness to cap oil production. Nevertheless, I don't think there will be any need for anyone to cap the output, as the spot price of oil is in the upper 40s now. If it gets any higher, more shale wells will come online. OPEC wouldn't want that.

Price of oil keeps creeping up, with Brent Crude now about $49, close to the price Saudi Arabia would like it to be i.e. as high as it can go without bringing back the oil that's more expensive to produce (shale etc). The reason for wanting an immediate freeze back in February, when the price was just coming off lows in the twenties, is no longer there. A freeze may not even be an item for serious discussion at the forthcoming OPEC meeting.
With Goldman Sachs reporting that there is now a supply shortfall and prices heading close to $50 a barrel the urgency for Iran to agree a production cap has reduced considerably.

I agree with @DAL that their infrastructure is not ready to equal the oil production of other oil nations or the profits, so a cap is not in their future. Also, by not applying the cap in the near future, they give Russia and Saudi Arabia another economic swift  kick in the leg,  giving competitors more pressure to maintain domestic power by cutting other services and social needs. This is something that lifts Iran and becomes an economic burden to other oil nation producers.
Iran needs the revenue, but is having infrastructure problems so the expected increase in supply may be slower.

This will be a close one.
"Lifting sales to the pre-sanctions level could pave the way for Iran and other Opec members to talk about limits on production in as soon as one or two months, Rokneddin Javadi, managing director at National Iranian Oil Co, said on Thursday."

No interest for Iran expect capture market share. Low lifting cost and greed of easy currency will pressure increasing volume despite ire of other producers. Russia-Iran axis would be the possible pivot, but only short lived psychology, since the global volumes are still marginal. Classic case of price war based on volume.
Iran seems quite happy to continue pumping, and now Saudi have given up on the proposed freeze too:
NO change. Hard not to go to 0 but, considering previous surprises will remain @ 1% up through the next OPEC meeting on 2/6/16 in Vienna. .http://www.opec.org/opec_web/en/311.htm
Down 50% to be closer to consensus. Not sure the consensus correctly captures all factors that might nudge Iran to some kind of a deal. Will see soon.

Reducing my forecast due to the fact that Iranian Oil minister seems keen to make sure they are producing 4 million barrels and is not willing to consider the 500,000 barrels of condensate (http://www.presstv.ir/Detail/2016/05/06/464312/Iran-says-ready-to-join-oil-freeze-plan/ and http://www.presstv.ir/Detail/2016/05/09/464762/Iran-again-rejects-joining-oil-freeze-plan/), and also that the initial article quotes the Tasnim news agency, but I cannot find any such report on their site.
8% because of the volatility of the news reports don't really allow to go any lower in my view.

Saudi's replace oil minister. Highly questionable if there is any opportunity for anyone to join a Saudi led production freeze.
http://oilprice.com/Energy/Energy-General/What-OPEC-Has-To-Fear-From-The-New-Saudi-Oil-Minister.html
New Saudi objective to diversify economy seems to lead to continued Saudi oil production, reliance on maintaining high price is gone.

There is an OPEC Meeting in July that could for a freeze and looking at how this will be accomplished.  The only requirement is for Iran to agree to a freeze without necessarily working out the deal.   However, still skeptical about Iran's intention since the OPEC Minister has not officially provided the position of Iran.
Updating on change in the saudi oil minister
Down 30% based on weekend developments and short time frame.
I'm dropping back down based on the various pieces of evidence provided by @BG1 and @austerity.

Following @austerity and @BG1. The latest developments in Saudi Arabia (change of oil minister etc putting power more obviously in the hands of the hawkish Deputy Crown Prince) and statements from Iran indicate little prospect of mutual agreement. The OPEC meeting on 02 June will probably be decisive, but if oil prices continue to rise, the incentive to cap will be reduced.
Adjusting down 20 because the statement issued by Iran on Friday isn't affecting the oil price in any significant way. I have also not seen any larger newspapers reporting it.

Probably the most divergent question and our consensus is strongly not forecasting any change in stance. However, there are three majoe points. One, Saudi oil minister change means new policy and we could see some oil resolution soon, as the previous one lost his job after a long track record on no progress on production agreement. Two, Iran is back up to 4m bpd already, a level it is previously indicated as the comfort level for them. Three, Venezuela is reeling and would be very very blatantly asking for a cap on production.
The new oil minister in Saudi Arabia is likely to contribute more to Iran's decision in favor of capping oil output before July 1, 2016
ego, revenge, marking territories, independence, internal politics, etc

"Saudi Arabia's new energy minister said on Sunday the world's largest crude exporter was committed to meeting demand for hydrocarbons from its customers and would maintain its petroleum policies.

I think that there will be agreement at the next OPEC meeting regarding the freeze in production - given Iran's production (current) quota's, meeting the output range prior to sanctions.  The agreement however is different implementation.  The meeting undoubtedly work on specifics and target actionable requirements.  When states implement the agreement, the IFP date will have reached its horizon.
Highly doubt that for now - after OPEC negotiations, Iran won't cap its oil output before it reaches the pre-ban levels. Probability of getting on this level by 1 July is very low.

Once again one feels flummoxed by the question's wording.  If Iran announces tomorrow that they have agreed to cap production in August, that is an agreement before 1 July to cap output, but it is not an agreement to cap output before 1 July.  Words matter.  I continue to pretend that the latter meaning--the cap has to take effect before 1 July--is what the Great and Good mean by this, but one would not be surprised to be taken by surprise on this topic.
Up 14% on @jhoward link. Iran should be expected to be on message regardless of what outside oil experts may anticipate.
@speculator502 I think this helps answer where Iran stands in terms of capping production in relation to pre sanction levels.

It seems as though there is some confusion about the question.  I'm reading the question as Iran formally agrees to a cap before 1 July 2016, but that it may take time for actual production to match the agreed level.

As discussed would drop probability if price remained in range, also taking opportunity to reassess my logic.
Still believe my interpretation of question is correct, ie Iran capping at pre-sanction levels not a high bar, but my assumption, that Iran and Saudi Arabia would see through their enmity for the benefits of their own mutual advantage by surpassing that low bar was off. Will move it down to 7% on following basis:
- it still makes sense to agree to freeze/cap to more concretely floor prices

Iran isn't inclined to agree to a cap. Nor does OPEC expect them to.  Saudi Arabia is in the driver's seat and has oil prices about where they want them.  Low prices have reduced US output which has made room for Iran increases.
Dropping 1% to be below consensus (doesn't matter much with regard to scoring, but it helps me keep track of my overall arc).
Calling it based on the non-results of the Doha meeting. But a bit of palace intrigue meant to divide Iran and Russia?
Only if they get compensated for their sacrifice, otherwise they want to enjoy their freedom to sell.

There were reports circulating as early as today that leading oil exporters held a meeting to discuss capping production. These meetings with countries like Russia and Qatar were in attendance but Iran was not in attendance leading the world to believe that they have no interest in placing a cap on its oil production since economic sanctions were lifted earlier this year.
In my opinion, the agreement to cap its production can be reach before meeting their goal (4k b/d).

Down to zero on news that the Doha meeting could not agree on a freeze, primarily because Saudi Arabia insisted that there would be no freeze without Iran. Iran had already made it clear it would keep increasing production till it reached pre-sanction levels, not expected before 2017.
According to the Doha meeting today, Iran has no plans to limit its oil production before this July because it need the revenue.

Iran's stated policy is that it will not discuss capping or curtailing until reaching its pre-sanction production of 4.5 million barrels per day. At a growth rate of 0.3 million barrels per day per quarter, they would not reach pre-sanction levels until mid-2017

Iran most likely not even sending junior representation (2% - given twist and turns, might still be some chance)
Saudi concern that prices above 60 would lead to higher investment, so chance of deal diminishes to 30% (giving some credibility to the logic that without Iran there, by making deal Saudi show that Iran is not an important player)
Keep the rest the same.
Overall: 12 - still high compared to everyone on the perhaps stubborn premise that forward capping their production at pre-sanction levels, doesn't really cost them anything. If oil price remains above 40-45, will reduce this further.
They're giving the meeting a miss, and there is no economic or market reason why they should do this for a while yet.
I agree with @BG1 that chances of Iran agreeing are low.
My bias is that reasonable minds can find a way when given an opportunity. However,every bit of circumstantial evidence on this bias keeps pointing in the other direction.

Twofold:
1 Political/Religious: With the lift of the sanctions Iran will try to enhance its Position as a counterweight to Saudi-Arabia in the Region. Low oil-prices at the Moment 
do harm SA more than Iran. So keeping up the oil Output is a means to level the playing field.
2 Interior/Economic: The Need for Investment to upgrade the infrastructure and economy is big in Iran. Large sums of cash will be needed to catch up.

Technically, they already have agreed to cap output - but only when production reaches pre-sanctions levels around 4mn b/d. I take this question to mean that they will agree to cap output around current levels. Unlikely. OPEC, as an organization, has shown little ability to coordinate despite the drop in oil prices. Any significant cuts at this point which drives global energy prices higher is only likely to benefit smaller shale producers in the U.S., thereby supporting one of the main drivers behind the drop in prices.

Iran has every reason to treat the cap argument as another proxy war with SA and seems likely to want to reduce SA's influence over OPEC or oil trading in general. The state may pay lip service to price stability but is presumably aware that the continuing low price will not just hurt SA politically but also lead to a number of the higher-cost/more speculative oil producers going to the wall, which will lead to greater stabilisation in the price. If Iran can effectively force SA to cut production that is all to Iran's benefit at home and in terms of geopolitical status. It is possible that Iran may choose to agree to a high future cap, but I can't see that being a popular move at home.

Iran has said it will not cap and they wish to reach 4M within a few months 
I donot see why Iran should cap , they have endured a forced cap for many years.
It make no sense for Iran to do it , unless they get something in return worth their while.
Iranians have committed to increase volumes 
I hope a lesson learned would be instead of depending on oil 
They  start and invest in alternative sources of energy.
All these counties need to invest in other renewable energy sources.
I believe this is their opportunity to make hay while the sun shines.  Even with prices at current low levels, a small percentage of much is better than 100% of little.

Bouncing back up from 5. It won't cost Iran anything to say it will cap its output at something like 4 million bpd after it reaches that level in the future. However, the fine print of this question indicates that Iran's agreement to a cap should be part of a larger OPEC agreement, and so far OPEC (effectively Saudi Arabia) seems unlikely to agree to a cap while Iran keeps increasing production.
It just dawned on me that agreeing to a cap is not the same as agreeing to a reduction.  Iran could agree to a cap of 4mbd!

Recent developments point towards the opposite occurring. Iranian state television reported on April the 5th that they plan to boost production of oil and gas condensate from its current 2 million barrels a day to 4 million barrels per day by March of next year. Unlike the Saudi's who pushed for OPEC nations to maintain production levels in order to make American Shale production unprofitable and to weaken Russia for backing the president of Syria, Bashar Al-Assad. Post sanction lift Iran wants to boost oil production which had been dampened from it pre-sanction 2.5 million barrels a day to a measly on avg. 1.35 million barrels a day.

(no change) Here is one way to consider this question. The oil market/business is a mess. We know why Iran won't cooperate with KSA and that it isn't in Iran's immediate interest to actually cut production sooner than they hope. OTOH, they need to be seen as being fully integrated with the world economy and being recognized for their economic potential. It costs nothing to attend the meeting in Doha (planned) and nothing to announce that they will do something in the future to support stable oil prices. No clarification whether just an announcement for something in the future would be enough, but I suspect it would suffice. As a comparison class, OPEC decisions also have been notoriously leaky. YMMV

Reducing from 45 on news that Saudi Arabia has once again stated it will not freeze if Iran doesn't, whereas at best Iran may only agree not to exceed 4 million barrels per day once it reaches that goal (which won't be for several months yet). Since this question requires Iran's agreement to be part of a larger OPEC  deal, the chances of this happening soon are low.

I've been looking through the thread and just noticed the differing interpretations over the meaning of the question. I took it to mean "cap its output before July 1." I see that "make an agreement, before July 1, to cap its output at some point" is also a valid interpretation.
Maybe later, after they have been pumping for a while.
Saudi Arabia is pushing for this so of course they won't.

Based on comments from the Iran oil minster, they are looking to reach pre-sanction production levels of 4 million barrels a day. By the end of March, they are at 2 million barrels a day. To close that gap in the next 3 months would be a tall order, so It seems pretty unlikely that Iran would agree to cap output in that timeframe. Other factors may drive them to consider a cap in the next 3 months, but so far the signals from Tehran show they have no desire to slow down.

I presume there is enough distrust between oil producers to think that any type of agreement to curtail production is likely to fail. Cartels rarely work, especially when their members are at odds. Also, it's hard to see why Iran would forfeit the opportunity to export oil just as the embargo was lifted. They will choose to sell high volume at low prices with new trading partners than lower volume at low prices.

It's true Iran needs and wants to continue it's output. But it also needs the price of oil to come up at some point. Saudi Arabia can play this game longer than Iran.
Breakeven cost of output is $93 per barrel for Saudi Arabia, $136 for Iran. 
http://marketrealist.com/analysis/stock-analysis/energy-power/upsteam-oil-gas/charts/?featured_post=1043318&featured_chart=1043322
Compared to Iran, Saudi Arabis is still flush with cash. GDP per capita favors Saudi Arabia as well. 
There are a host of other variables here as well. But for now, I'm not willing to start as low as other forecasters. 
Will an output freeze by other countries (excluding Iran) be enough to push up the price of oil to make this more sustainable for Iran? Perhaps.  
I'll lower my forecast by about 10% every month for the next three months...it may seem high now...but Iran could decide to make a modest, temporary reduction in output to close the gap between supply and demand. Such a move may not amount to a significant reduction in output, but may influence the market.

Iran is not going to play nice with Saudi Arabia, and they shouldn't. By obeying OPEC, they give OPEC power. That's the last thing Iran wants to do. I honestly believe they are looking at toppling Saudi as the Middle East financial powerhouse, so there's no way they're going to undercut their own efforts.
Not going to freeze production until it reaches pre sanction levels on the market.

as has been remarked elsewhere a backlog of repair/maintenance likely needed (which is also likely to impact on foreign contracts which take time) + Iran, as the aggrieved/sanctioned party is likely to be rather adamant about maintaining independence/not giving in until quite satisfied (revenge?) to exhibit strength - may also be a reassuring signal to the hardliners
Iran needs the revenue from oil sales even at very low prices. Iran also wants to reaquire steady customers for it's oil exports.
Iran is not making any money on oil now, they need the cash, when they have a little financial relief they will be more susceptible to pressure.

Iran wants to continue ramping up production and currently there is no discussion of freezing their output. not only are they looking to gain market share on exports, an internal economic recovery will also drive demand for oil. lead up to the DOHA talks on April 17th will provide a better indicator of their position.

Iran is highly dependable on its oil production which would mean they don't agree to a cap. However, since their oil resources are depleted by 75% already, it is also in Iran's governments interest to stabilize the output and send a signal to the markets that the prices need to go up. Oil output in my opinion also does not include the reserves they put aside over the last couple of years which they will now sell. They could agree to a cap in output and still sell more oil. Another reason I set my forecast in the 40% range is related to political side deals. They want to show the outside world that they can play ball and an oil output cap (after fighting it hard in public) will send this message.
As their primary source of revenue, I do not see Iran capping oil output anytime soon.
I don't see Iran capping oil output anytime soon.

Iran is highly unlikely to agree to cap its oil supply before 1 July 2016. There are two reasons two for this. 1. There is no agreement between OPEC and non-OPEC countries over capping oil. Iran, though supporting the freeze, has clearly said that it would not freeze the production until it reaches its pre-sanction levels. It has been quit categorical that like other countries it too needs time to build its market.

Iran will not cap its oil output this year. They realize that by agreeing to a cap, they are doing something that would benefit their main rival, Saudi Arabia, more than it would benefit themselves. Iran has not (legally) been able to sell oil internationally for decades, and they don't get much benefit from holding it within their borders (except for domestic use). They don't see any economic benefit from keeping their excess, and they need hard currency.

They have no incentive to agree to an oil cap - especially given that they need the monies to pursue their internal and external groups support (Hezbollah, Hamas, Revolutionary Guards, etc.) as well as not wanting to help the Saudi's in any way. Also, as we have seen time and time again Cartel "agreements" generally do not work.

The question is not asking what output cap Iran might agree to. As part of a general OPEC deal Iran might agree a cap that is higher than it has been exporting. i.e. agree not to expand exports beyond a certain amount.

Seems unlikely given their return to the market. Extraction costs are amongst the lowest ( http://marketrealist.com/2016/01/crude-oils-total-cost-production-impacts-major-oil-producers/ ) and regaining market-share is the priority in China and other markets, such as Europe:
July 1st seems too close form this to take place.

Iran has indicated that it will continue to increase its oil production in order to regain its share of the global market since it is no longer constrained by international sanctions.   It has also indicated that it will continue production and supply to the global market and consider a cap once it has reached a 4 million/bpd output.   It will now participate in the upcoming OPEC meeting (along with non-OPEC members) in April to discuss a freeze in production in order to stabilize global price levels.  Iraq has filled the production of Iranian quota's since the implementation of sanctions.  It now holds the position that it will only participate in the April meeting if all members are involve and agree to a freeze.  Russia, bilaterally supporting Iran on this issue, has also indicated (despite its participation in April) that continued production increases by Iran are justified.

Iran says it will "join discussions" to cap once it reaches 4m barrels a day. they produced 3.1m in Feb, an increase of 187K from January. Assuming they ramp up to 4m at the same pace, that is 3.287 in March, 3.475ish in April etc. Not enough time unless they really ramp it up. and they have no incentive to do anything but what they have said they will do.
My estimate is they'll try to wait out the economy until the price of oil returns to a higher level.
According to Iranian officials they will not cap until they are producing 4 million barrels a day. At their current rate that will not happen until the second week in August.
I am going to start out very skeptical, and may just swing to a big zero.  Here is why:
I think Iran would only consider this kind of move if petrol prices drop to $ 20 levels again, not impossible in the next 4 months, not exactly the most probable scenario.
Iran just gone out of sanctions,  in desperate need for cash.
Most sanctions were just lifted. It would be surprising if Iran cut back on one of its main exports at this time.
Cap unlikely, but there is a possibility of capping at higher than current production

Now that Iran can openly sell oil again, it doesn't make sense for them to voluntarily restrict themselves.  Some hard currency is better than none.  They are involved with the Saudis in regional competition makes this a non-starter because it would reward the Saudis for keeping their production up.

If Iran were going to cap its output, rather through OPEC or by itself, I believe it would have done so by now, because pressures haven't changed in the last few months.  Oil is rebounding slightly, which further decreases the likelihood of Iran implementing a cap.
On balance I think it unlikley given their recent statements and their need to increase oil exports. In addition they would be unlikely to follow a Saudi initiative within OPEC to reduce output

There doesn't seem to be a substantial economic benefit for them to cap output when they just got access to the oil markets. Oil price has bounced somewhat off its lows. However, the "caps" are high so the impact is rather minimal. It is easy to say "yes" to something that has little impact. At first I thought close to zero, but considering the possibility of weak caps, I'm coming in higher. Also, there could be a workaround to allow for export of the stored oil Iran has put aside during the sanctions and to not include this strictly in the caps. Maybe they implement a Iran daily cap of 3 MBD, but allow for additional export of the reserve.

Considering the election runoff delays and lack of clear direction, expecting a unified policy on economics let alone a cap in oil output by July appears to be unrealistic.  There is currently no cap so I start at 0%.  I'll discount up to 2% for a black swan but otherwise I'd be at 0%.

Iran says it will reach 4 million barrels a day by June and therefore could agree to the caps by July 1, but Russia seems willing to give them an exception to the caps since they have had lower production due to sanctions.  If Iran is given the exception, I think they would use that beyond July 1.
Iran has said it will not consider a freeze on production till it achieves 4 million barrels per day, which isn't going to happen in the next three or four months.

Off the top of my head, reasons why they won't
-Saudi Arabia is a part of the deal
-why would they care about Venezuela or any of the other countries that are suffering from low prices more than they are?
-wouldn't increasing volume be a far easier way for Iran to increase oil revenue?
-what chance would capping production have of increasing prices when US shale oil could so easily rebound?

Fat chance. Iran has been cut off from much of the international market for some time, and its erstwhile partners of OPEC--many of whom are gulf Arab states--have more than business interests in hurting Iranian output. It will be prudent to keep an eye on this, though.
They appear to be disinclined.  More later.
